elements.content: Seven coordination polymers, namely [Zn(BPTC)0.5(L1)0.5(H2O)] (1), [Zn2(BPTC)(L2)]·H2O (2), [Zn2(BPTC)(L3)2]·3H2O (3), [Zn2.5(BPTC)(L4)(OH)(H2O)] (4), [Zn2(BPTC)(L5)(H2O)2]·3H2O (5), [Cd2(BPTC)(L5)(H2O)]·H2O (6), and [Cd(BPTC)0.5(L6)]·H2O (7), where L1 = 4,4′-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)bibenzene, L2 = 4,4′-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, L3 = 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)butane, L4 = 1,4-bis(2-ethyl-imidazol-1-yl)butane, L5 = 1,3-bis[2-(2-pyridyl)imidazol-1-ylmethyl]benzene, L6 = 1,2-bis[2-(2-pyridyl)imidazol-1-ylmethyl]benzene, and BPTC = 3,3′,4,4′-benzophenone tetracarboxylate ligand, have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Their structures have been determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses and further characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectra, and thermogravimetric analyses. The structure of 1 exhibits a (4,6)-connected network with a (44·62)(44·610·8) topology formed by L1 ligands connecting BPTC−Zn sheets. The structure of 2 is a chiral 3D network in which there exists a Zn−O helical chain which may transmit the chirality to the whole framework. In compound 3, multicarboxylate ligands link L3−metal helical chains to generate a layer which is further connected by intermolecular H bonds to form a 3D supramolecular structure. In compound 4, the L4−Zn sheets are connected by BPTC pillars to generate a 3D framework with a distorted α-Po topology. Compound 5 shows infinite chains. Compound 6 shows two kinds of novel infinite chains which are linked by π−π stacking interactions to form 2D supramolecular sheets. Compound 7 is a (3,4)-connected framework with a (62·8)2(62·84) topology. The structural differences among 1–4 indicate the importance of the flexibility of the ligands (L1−L4) for the framework formation of the coordination polymers. By varying the angular feature of the ligands (L5 and L6), compounds 5–7 have been separated completely. In additon, the luminescent properties of these compounds are discussed.

elements.content: Seven coordination polymers of d10 metals with 3,3′,4,4′-benzophenone tetracarboxylate acid and five different flexible and angular characteristic neutral ligands based on imidazole have been synthesized and characterized, and their various structures, affected by different ligands, are discussed in detail.

elements.content: In recent years, the rational design and assembly of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) with well-regulated network structures have received remarkable attention in order to develop new functional materials with potential applications. Among the numerous metal−organic coordination polymers, the construction of helical coordination polymers has generated a great deal more of attention because of the frequent appearance of helical structures in proteins, collagens, quartz, single-walled carbon nanotubes, and many more natural or artificial fiber-type derivatives. Nevertheless, it is still a great challenge to predict the exact structures and compositions of polymeric compounds assembled in a helical motif, although some structures with various helices have been reported in MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, the rational design and assembly of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with well-regulated network structures have received remarkable attention in order to develop new functional materials with potential applications. Among the numerous metal-organic coordination polymers, the construction of helical coordination polymers has generated a great deal more of attention because of the frequent appearance of helical structures in proteins, collagens, quartz, single-walled carbon nanotubes, and many more natural or artificial fiber-type derivatives. Nevertheless, it is still a great challenge to predict the exact structures and compositions of polymeric compounds assembled in a helical motif, although some structures with various helices have been reported in MOFs.

elements.content: According to previous literature, the construction of MOFs mainly depends on the nature of the organic ligands (spacers) and metal ions (nodes). Among various organic ligands, multicarboxylate ligands are selected as multifunctional organic ligands, not only because of their various coordination modes to metal ions, resulting from completely or partially deprotonated sites allowing for the large diversity of topologies, but also because of their ability to act as H-bond acceptors and donors to assemble supramolecular structures. For example, aromatic multicarboxylates (benzene dicarboxylate, benzene tricarboxylate, 4,4′-oxybis(benzoate), and ethylenedi(4-oxybenzoate)) have been investigated widely for the design and synthesis of open framework complexes. However, investigations on H4BPTC (BPTC = 3,3′,4,4′-benzophenone tetracarboxylate) are scarce. The completely or partly deprotonated H4BPTC ligands have irregular orientations when they coordinate to metals to compensate the charge or pH adjusters, which may produce various structural topologies, large pores, and different helixes, owing to their tetradentate carboxylate arms and their steric bulk. On the other hand, the results of our previous studies show that neutral bis(imidazole) ligands exhibit the special ability to coordinate to various metal centers in multiform coordination fashions to formulate the compounds.

Among various organic ligands, multicarboxylate ligands are selected as multifunctional organic ligands, not only because of their various coordination modes to metal ions, resulting from completely or partially deprotonated sites allowing for the large diversity of topologies, but also because of their ability to act as H-bond acceptors and donors to assemble supramolecular structures. For example, aromatic multicarboxylates (benzene dicarboxylate, benzene tricarboxylate, 4,4'-oxybis(benzoate), and ethylenedi(4-oxybenzoate)) have been investigated widely for the design and synthesis of open framework complexes. However, investigations on H4BPTC (BPTC = 3,3',4,4'-benzophenone tetracarboxylate) are scarce. The completely or partly deprotonated H4BPTC ligands have irregular orientations when they coordinate to metals to compensate the charge or pH adjusters, which may produce various structural topologies, large pores, and different helixes, owing to their tetradentate carboxylate arms and their steric bulk. On the other hand, the results of our previous studies show that neutral bis(imidazole) ligands exhibit the special ability to coordinate to various metal centers in multiform coordination fashions to formulate the compounds.

elements.content: Taking these properties into account, we selected H4BPTC, a series of bis(imidazole) ligands with different flexible substituent groups and angular characteristics (Chart ) as organic neutral ligands and luminescent d10 ions (ZnII and CdII) as metal centers to construct the MOFs. Fortunately, our research efforts led to seven novel compounds, namely [Zn(BPTC)0.5(L1)0.5(H2O)] (1), [Zn2(BPTC)(L2)]·H2O (2), [Zn2(BPTC)(L3)2]·3H2O (3), [Zn2.5(BPTC)(L4)(OH)(H2O)] (4), [Zn2(BPTC)(L5)(H2O)2]·3H2O (5), [Cd2(BPTC)(L5)(H2O)]·H2O (6), and [Cd(BPTC)0.5(L6)]·H2O (7), which were isolated by hydrothermal methods.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

Chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. Ligands 4,4'-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)bibenzene (L1), 4,4'-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (L2), 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)butane (L3), and 2-(2-pyridyl)imidazole were prepared according to the literature.

elements.content: A mixture of 2-ethylimidazole (6.80 g, 100 mmol) and NaOH (4.00 g, 100 mmol) in DMSO (20 mL) was stirred at 60 °C for 1 h, and the 1,4-bis(chloro)butane (6.35 g, 50 mmol) was added. The mixture was cooled to room temperature after being stirred at 60 °C for 24 h. The DMSO was then removed and extracted with ethyl acetate (100 × 3). The extracted solution was put in a water bath (90 °C) for 3 h, and the colorless oil L4 was obtained in 70% yield (8.61 g).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 1,4-Bis(2-ethyl-imidazol-1-yl)butane (L4)

A mixture of 2-ethylimidazole (6.80 g, 100 mmol) and NaOH (4.00 g, 100 mmol) in DMSO (20 mL) was stirred at 60 °C for 1 h, and the 1,4-bis(chloro)butane (6.35 g, 50 mmol) was added. The mixture was cooled to room temperature after being stirred at 60 °C for 24 h. The DMSO was then removed and extracted with ethyl acetate (100 × 3). The extracted solution was put in a water bath (90 °C) for 3 h, and the colorless oil L4 was obtained in 70% yield (8.61 g).

elements.content: A mixture of 2-(2-pyridyl)imidazole (7.25 g, 50 mmol) and NaOH (2.00 g, 50 mmol) in DMSO (20 mL) was stirred at 60 °C for 1 h, and the 1,3-bis(chloromethyl)benzene (4.35 g, 25 mmol) was added. The mixture was cooled to room temperature after being stirred at 60 °C for 24 h and poured into 200 mL of water. A yellow solid formed immediately, which was isolated by filtration in 80% yield (7.84 g) after drying in air.

A yellow solid formed immediately, which was isolated by filtration in 80% yield (7.84 g) after drying in air.

elements.content:
L6 was prepared in the same way as L5, by using 1,2-bis(chloromethyl)benzene instead of 1,3-bis(chloromethyl)benzene (75% yield (7.35 g)).

Synthesis of [Zn(BPTC)<sub>0.5</sub>(L<sup>1</sup>)<sub>0.5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)] (1)

A mixture of 3,3′,4,4′-benzophenone tetracarboxylic dianhydride (0.16 g, 0.50 mmol), L1 (0.15 g, 0.50 mmol), Zn(OAc)2·2H2O (0.17 g, 0.75 mmol), NaOH (0.08 g, 2.00 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) was stirred for 1 h and sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel container. The container was heated to 150 °C and held at this temperature for 72 h. It was then cooled to 100 °C at a rate of 5 °C·h−1 and held at this temperature for 8 h. Further cooling to 30 °C at a rate of 3 °C·h−1 followed. The initial and final pH values for 1 were 7.02 and 6.80, respectively. The colorless crystals of 1 were collected in 50.6% yield (0.164 g). Anal. Calcd for C18.5H14N2O5.5Zn (417.69): C, 53.45; H, 3.39; N, 6.74. Found: C, 53.41; H, 3.36; N, 6.73. IR (cm−1): 3410 (s), 3135 (w), 1662 (s), 1546 (s), 1496 (s), 1413 (s), 1379 (s), 1278 (m), 1245 (s), 1124 (w), 1094 (m), 1006 (w), 930 (w), 856 (m), 810 (m), 752 (s), 653 (m).

elements.content: The C, H, and N elemental analysis was conducted on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 400–4000 cm−1 on a Mattson Alpha-Centauri spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Perkin-Elmer TG-7 analyzer heated from 35 to 600 °C under N2. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were collected on a Rigaku Dmax 2000 X-ray diffractometer with graphite-monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) and 2θ ranging from 3 to 60°. The emission/excitation spectra were recorded on a Varian Cary Eclipse spectrometer.

elements.content: Single-crystal XRD data for compounds 1–7 were recorded on a Bruker Apex CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. Absorption corrections were applied using the multiscan technique. All the structures were solved by Direct Method of SHELXS-97 and refined by the full-matrix least-squares techniques by using the SHELXL-97 program within WINGX. Nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic temperature parameters. The hydrogen atoms of the organic ligands were refined as rigid groups. Some of the H atoms from the water molecules in compounds 2 and 5 could not be positioned reliably. Other H atoms from the water molecules were located with difference Fourier maps. The detailed crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for 1–7 are summarized in Table .

Selected bond distances and angles for compounds 1–7 are listed in (see the ). Compound 1 consists of one kind of Zn cation, one kind of BPTC anion, and one kind of L1 ligand. The square-pyramidal arrangement {ZnNO4} around the ZnII cation is completed by three carboxylate O atoms from three different BPTC anions, one water molecule, and one N atom from the L1 ligand (Figurea). The Zn−O and Zn−N bond lengths are all within the normal ranges. BPTC anions coordinate to six ZnII cations (Charta) to form a 2D polymeric layer (Figureb). Within this layer, two adjacent ZnII atoms are bridged by two carboxylate groups to give a bimetallic unit [Zn2(CO2)2] (Figurec). L1 ligands exhibit an S-shaped conformation () and connect the Zn−BPTC layers as pillars to generate a 3D structure (Figured). If the [Zn2(CO2)2] unit is considered as a six-connected node (connecting to four BPTC anions and two L1 ligands), the BPTC anion can be considered as a four-connected node (connecting to four bimetallic units [Zn2(CO2)2]), and the structure of 1 can be classified as a (4,6)-connected network with a (44·6)(44·6·8) topology (Figurese and ). In addition, the 3D structure of 1 is further stabilized by intermolecular H-bonding interactions ().

Structure Description of 1

Selected bond distances and angles for compounds 1-7 are listed in  (see the ). Compound 1 consists of one kind of Zn cation, one kind of BPTC anion, and one kind of L1 ligand. The square-pyramidal arrangement {ZnNO4} around the ZnII cation is completed by three carboxylate O atoms from three different BPTC anions, one water molecule, and one N atom from the L1 ligand (Figurea). The Zn-O and Zn-N bond lengths are all within the normal ranges. BPTC anions coordinate to six ZnII cations (Charta) to form a 2D polymeric layer (Figureb). Within this layer, two adjacent ZnII atoms are bridged by two carboxylate groups to give a bimetallic unit [Zn2(CO2)2] (Figurec). L1 ligands exhibit an S-shaped conformation () and connect the Zn-BPTC layers as pillars to generate a 3D structure (Figured). If the [Zn2(CO2)2] unit is considered as a six-connected node (connecting to four BPTC anions and two L1 ligands), the BPTC anion can be considered as a four-connected node (connecting to four bimetallic units [Zn2(CO2)2]), and the structure of 1 can be classified as a (4,6)-connected network with a (44⋅6)(44⋅6⋅8) topology (Figurese and ). In addition, the 3D structure of 1 is further stabilized by intermolecular H-bonding interactions ().

elements.content: As shown in Figurea, compound 2 consists of two kinds of ZnII cations, one kind of BPTC anion, and one kind of L2 ligand. Zn1 is five-coordinated to four carboxylate O atoms from three different BPTC anions and one N atom from one L2 ligand, and it shows a distorted trigonal-bipyramidal geometry. Zn2 is four-coordinated to three carboxylate O atoms from three different BPTC anions and one N atom from one L2 ligand, and it shows a distorted tetrahedral geometry. Each BPTC anion coordinates to six ZnII cations (Chart b). One kind of phthalate group of BPTC anion links the Zn1 cation to form a Zn−O helical chain (Figure b). The other kind of phthalate group links the Zn2 cation to generate a double chain (). The two kinds of chains are linked by carbonyl groups of BPTC anions to form a Zn−BPTC sheet (Figurec). These Zn−BPTC sheets are pillared by S-shaped L2 ligands () to give a chiral 3D framework (Figured).

elements.content: The crystal structure of 3 consists of two kinds of ZnII cations, two kinds of L3 ligands, and one kind of BPTC anion (Figurea). Each ZnII cation is coordinated to two carboxylate O atoms from two BPTC anions and two N atoms from different L3 ligands, completing a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry. The two types of L3 ligands show distinct TGT (T = trans and G = gauche) and GTG conformations () and bridge two types of ZnII ions to generate an infinite helical chain with a pitch of 14.700 Å (Figure b). Each BPTC anion shows a tetra(monodentate) coordination mode (Chartc) and links the helical chains to generate a 2D sheet (Figuresc and ) by coordinating to four ZnII cations. Furthermore, the water molecules in the sheets stabilize the 2D structure by H bonds. These 2D sheets are connected by H bonds to form a 3D supramolecular framework (Figured).

elements.content: Water clusters have been widely studied both theoretically and experimentally. A variety of water clusters [(H2O) n , n = 2–18], found in a number of crystal hosts, have been characterized and display different configurations. As shown in Figuree, two lattice–water molecules in 3 form a dimer with a OW…OW distance of 2.941(7) Å, whereas these distances in regular ice, liquid water, and water vapor are 2.74, 2.85, and 2.98 Å, respectively. The water molecule O3W donates H bonds to one carboxylate O atom, and O2W#1 in turn donates H bonds to one carboxylate O atom. So, the water clusters are important for this kind of structural type.

elements.content: X-ray analyses reveal that compound 4 contains three kinds of ZnII ions, two kinds of L4 ligands, and one kind of BPTC ligand (Figurea). It is interesting that the three ZnII ions exhibit coordination numbers of 4, 5, and 6, respectively. Zn1 shows an octahedral geometry and is six-coordinated to four carboxylate O atoms from different BPTC ligands and two (OH)− groups. Zn2 shows a tetrahedral geometry and is four-coordinated to two carboxylate O atoms from two BPTC ligands, one (OH)− group, and one N atom from the L4 ligand. Zn3 completes a trigonal-bipyramidal coordination geometry to two carboxylate O atoms from different BPTC ligands, one (OH)− group, one N atom from the L4 ligand, and one water molecule. The two kinds of L4 ligands exhibit similar TTT conformations () and link Zn2 and Zn3 ions to generate an interesting meso-helical chain2o, with Zn2−O10 and Zn3−O10 bonds (Figureb). Each Zn1 ion is coordinated to one O10 atom and one symmetry-related O10 atom from different helical chains. Therefore, these helical chains are linked by Zn1 to extend into a Zn−L sheet with a (4,4) topology (Figurec). So, one Zn1, two Zn2, two Zn3, and one (OH)− group compose a penta-core zinc cluster (). Two adjacent quinary-core zinc clusters from different Zn−L sheets are linked by two bis(monodentate)-bis(didentate) coordinated BPTC ligands (Chartd) to form a 3D structure (Figured). In this structure, if each penta-core zinc cluster is considered as a six-connecting node and BPTC and L4 ligands as linkers, compound 4 exhibits a distorted α-Po topology (Figuree).

elements.content: Compound 6 consists of two kinds of CdII cations, one kind of L5 ligand, and one kind of BPTC anion (Figurea). The Cd1 cation is coordinated to three carboxylate O atoms from three different BPTC anions and two N atoms from the same L5 ligand. In addition, two carboxylate O atoms weakly coordinate to a Cd1 cation with distances of 2.687(2) Å for Cd1−O5#3 and 2.696(3) Å for Cd1−O8. The Cd2 cation shows an octahedral coordination geometry {CdN2O4} which is completed by three carboxylate O atoms from two BPTC anions, one water molecule, and two N atoms from one L5 ligand. The Cd−O and Cd−N distances are quite similar to the normal Cd−O and Cd−N distances. Each BPTC anion coordinates to five Cd cations (Charte) to form a 1D chain. The U-shaped L5 ligands () coordinate to the Cd1 cation and the Cd2 cation in the same chain (Figure b). This stabilizes the chainlike structure.

The Cd1 cation is coordinated to three carboxylate O atoms from three different BPTC anions and two N atoms from the same L5 ligand. In addition, two carboxylate O atoms weakly coordinate to a Cd1 cation with distances of 2.687(2) Å for Cd1-O5#3 and 2.696(3) Å for Cd1-O8. The Cd2 cation shows an octahedral coordination geometry {CdN2O4} which is completed by three carboxylate O atoms from two BPTC anions, one water molecule, and two N atoms from one L5 ligand. The Cd-O and Cd-N distances are quite similar to the normal Cd-O and Cd-N distances. Each BPTC anion coordinates to five Cd cations (Charte) to form a 1D chain. The U-shaped L5 ligands () coordinate to the Cd1 cation and the Cd2 cation in the same chain (Figure b). This stabilizes the chainlike structure.

elements.content: In compound 7 (Figurea), each CdII cation is coordinated to three carboxylate O atoms from two BPTC anions and three N atoms from two L6 ligands to complete a distorted octahedral coordination geometry. Unexpectedly, the L6 ligand shows a monodentate-bidentate-chelating coordination mode and has an L-shaped conformation (). Each BPTC anion coordinates to four CdII cations (Chartf) to generate a 2D chiral layer (Figureb). Within the layer, all Cd−phthalate helical chains display the same chirality. The Cd−BPTC layers are linked by L6 ligands to form a 3D framework, in which the adjacent Cd−BPTC layers display opposite chirality (Figuresc and ). If BPTC anions are considered as four-connected nodes, CdII cations are considered as three-connected nodes, and the structure of 7 can be symbolized as a net with a (62·8)2(62·8) topology (Figuresd and ). In addition, the 3D structure is further stabilized by H bonds between water molecules and carboxylate O atoms.

Structure Description of 7

In compound 7 (Figurea), each CdII cation is coordinated to three carboxylate O atoms from two BPTC anions and three N atoms from two L6 ligands to complete a distorted octahedral coordination geometry. Unexpectedly, the L6 ligand shows a monodentate-bidentate-chelating coordination mode and has an L-shaped conformation (). Each BPTC anion coordinates to four CdII cations (Chartf) to generate a 2D chiral layer (Figureb). Within the layer, all Cd-phthalate helical chains display the same chirality. The Cd-BPTC layers are linked by L6 ligands to form a 3D framework, in which the adjacent Cd-BPTC layers display opposite chirality (Figuresc and ). If BPTC anions are considered as four-connected nodes, CdII cations are considered as three-connected nodes, and the structure of 7 can be symbolized as a net with a (62⋅8)2(62⋅8) topology (Figuresd and ). In addition, the 3D structure is further stabilized by H bonds between water molecules and carboxylate O atoms.

elements.content: From the structural descriptions above, it can be seen that the neutral ligands have a great influence on the frameworks of the complexes. As shown in Table, L1−L3 display bis(monodentate) bridging coordination modes with two imidazole N atoms coordinating to two different metal ions, and the linkers with different flexibilities play an important role in affecting the final structures in compounds 1–3. Although L3 and L4 ligands have similar flexibilities, the changes in the substituent groups in the 2- and 2′-positions can result in changes in the final frameworks for 3 and 4. In addition, L5 exhibits a bis(bidentate)-chelating bridging mode with four aromatic N atoms coordinating to two metal ions, and L6 exhibits a monodentate-bidentate-chelating bridging mode. Because of the different coordination modes and angular features of L5 and L6, compounds 5, 6, and 7 show different structural types, as expected.

In 1 and 2, L1 and L2 have similar S-shaped structures, with distances between two N atoms coordinating to metal centers of 14.469 and 10.878 Å, respectively. Biphenyl and phenyl groups are more rigid than butyl, so L1 and L2 connect to BPTC−Zn compositions as pillars to form the 3D structure. In 3, L3 ligands exhibit GGT and GTG coordination conformations with the shorter N···N distances of 5.813 and 7.888 Å, respectively. This makes L3 ligands coordinate to two metal centers from the same sheet, and compound 3 displays a 2D layerlike structure. For 4, when L4 coordinates to metal centers, the substituent groups in the 2- and 2′- positions of L4 can form a larger steric hindrance than those of L3, which makes fewer L4 [ZnNO3, ZnNO4, and ZnO6] coordinating to the same metal centers than L3 [ZnN2O2]. Meanwhile, L4 has a TTT coordination mode, with the N···N distances of 10.435 and 10.143 Å.

elements.content: In contrast to 1–4, in 5, the U-shaped L5 chelates to metal centers with a N···N distance of 5.962 Å, which reduces the chances of BPTC to coordinate to metal centers. Therefore, compound 5 shows an infinite chainlike structure. Compound 6 exhibits a structure similar to that of the U-shaped L5, with a N···N distance of 4.999 Å. From a theoretical point of view, the larger the angle between two 2-(2-pyridyl)imidazole groups, the larger the dimensions of the final compounds. Unexpectedly, in 7, the L6 ligand exhibits a monodentate-bidentate-chelating coordination mode and an L-shaped coordination conformation. The distance between two N atoms from imidazole is 7.578 Å. It is longer than that in 5 and 6, decreases steric repulsion for metal center, and causes metal centers to be coordinated to more other ligands to show a 3D network. For a smaller angular L6 ligand, the two 2-(2-pyridyl)imidazol groups are very close, and steric hindrance may cause them to rotate into directions different from those that stabilize the system.

elements.content: Luminescent compounds are currently of great interest because of their various applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, and electroluminescent display. The luminescent properties of Zn and Cd carboxylate compounds have been investigated. The photoluminescent spectra of compounds 1–7 and free neutral ligands L1−L were measured at room temperature (), and the emission maximums and excitation wavelengths are listed in Table. In order to understand the nature of the emission band, the photoluminescence properties of the 3,3′4,4′-benzophenone tetracarboxylic dianhydride ligand were analyzed. A weak emission (λmax = 557 nm) could be observed. In comparison to the free ligands, the emission maximums of compounds 1–7 have changed. This may be caused by a change in the HOMO and LUMO energy levels of deprotonated BPTC anions and neutral ligands coordinating to metal centers, a charge-transfer transition between ligands and metal centers, and a joint contribution of the intraligand transitions or charge-transfer transitions between the coordinated ligands and the metal centers.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

Luminescent compounds are currently of great interest because of their various applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, and electroluminescent display. The luminescent properties of Zn and Cd carboxylate compounds have been investigated. The photoluminescent spectra of compounds 1-7 and free neutral ligands L1-L were measured at room temperature (), and the emission maximums and excitation wavelengths are listed in Table. In order to understand the nature of the emission band, the photoluminescence properties of the 3,3'4,4'-benzophenone tetracarboxylic dianhydride ligand were analyzed. A weak emission (λmax = 557 nm) could be observed. In comparison to the free ligands, the emission maximums of compounds 1-7 have changed. This may be caused by a change in the HOMO and LUMO energy levels of deprotonated BPTC anions and neutral ligands coordinating to metal centers, a charge-transfer transition between ligands and metal centers, and a joint contribution of the intraligand transitions or charge-transfer transitions between the coordinated ligands and the metal centers.

elements.content: For compound 1, the weight loss corresponding to the release of water molecules is observed from 30 to 290 °C (obsd 4.2%, calcd 4.3%). The anhydrous composition begins to decompose at 310 °C. The TGA curve of 2 shows that this compound undergoes dehydration between 20 and 136 °C (obsd 5.6%, calcd 2.4%). The decomposition of the anhydrous composition occurs at 286 °C. For compound 3, the weight loss between 60 and 156 °C corresponds to the release of lattice−water molecules (obsd 5.6%, calcd 5.9%). The removal of the organic components occurs at 292 °C. In the case of 4, there is a weight loss of 3.2% (calcd 2.3%) below 189 °C (probably resulting from the very slow absorbability of guest molecules from the air at room temperature), and the decomposition of the anhydrous composition occurs at 297 °C. For 5, the weight loss of 9.2% (calcd 9.3%) between 20 and 285 °C is attributed to the release of the lattice−water and coordination molecules, and the release of the residual [Zn2(BPTC)(L5)] occurs at 290 °C. Compound 6 loses its water molecules between room temperature and 270 °C (obsd 3.6%, calcd 3.6%). The anhydrous [Cd2(BPTC)(L5)] is stable up to 345 °C. Compound 7 loses its water molecules between room temperature and 174 °C (obsd 2.4%, calcd 2.6%). The anhydrous composition is stable up to 269 °C.

elements.content: A variety of ZnII and CdII coordination polymers with different dimensions have been prepared under hydrothermal conditions by using BPTC and bis(imidazole) ligands with various features . The N-donor ligand, the organic acid, and the metal centers all affect the network structures of the coordination polymer products. The self-assembly of metal centers and various organic ligands into framework structures provides us with a potential method to form functional materials. The photoluminescence properties of the compounds indicate that they may be good candidates for luminescent materials. It is anticipated that more metal complexes containing neutral ligands and carboxylate anions with various interesting structural types as well as physical properties will be synthesized.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A variety of ZnII and CdII coordination polymers with different dimensions have been prepared under hydrothermal conditions by using BPTC and bis(imidazole) ligands with various features . The N-donor ligand, the organic acid, and the metal centers all affect the network structures of the coordination polymer products. The self-assembly of metal centers and various organic ligands into framework structures provides us with a potential method to form functional materials. The photoluminescence properties of the compounds indicate that they may be good candidates for luminescent materials. It is anticipated that more metal complexes containing neutral ligands and carboxylate anions with various interesting structural types as well as physical properties will be synthesized.

A mixture of 2-ethylimidazole (6.80 g, 100 mmol) and NaOH (4.00 g, 100 mmol) in DMSO (20 mL) was stirred at 60 °C for 1 h, and the 1,4-bis(chloro)butane (6.35 g, 50 mmol) was added. The mixture was cooled to room temperature after being stirred at 60 °C for 24 h. The DMSO was then removed and extracted with ethyl acetate (100 × 3). The extracted solution was put in a water bath (90 °C) for 3 h, and the colorless oil L4 was obtained in 70% yield (8.61 g).

Synthesis of 1,3-Bis[2-(2-pyridyl)imidazol-1-ylmethyl]benzene (L<sup>5</sup>)

A mixture of 2-(2-pyridyl)imidazole (7.25 g, 50 mmol) and NaOH (2.00 g, 50 mmol) in DMSO (20 mL) was stirred at 60 °C for 1 h, and the 1,3-bis(chloromethyl)benzene (4.35 g, 25 mmol) was added. The mixture was cooled to room temperature after being stirred at 60 °C for 24 h and poured into 200 mL of water. A yellow solid formed immediately, which was isolated by filtration in 80% yield (7.84 g) after drying in air.

Synthesis of 1,2-Bis[2-(2-pyridyl)imidazol-1-ylmethyl]benzene (L<sup>6</sup>)

L6 was prepared in the same way as L5, by using 1,2-bis(chloromethyl)benzene instead of 1,3-bis(chloromethyl)benzene (75% yield (7.35 g)).

Synthesis of [Zn(BPTC)<sub>0.5</sub>(L<sup>1</sup>)<sub>0.5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)] (1)

A mixture of 3,3′,4,4′-benzophenone tetracarboxylic dianhydride (0.16 g, 0.50 mmol), L1 (0.15 g, 0.50 mmol), Zn(OAc)2·2H2O (0.17 g, 0.75 mmol), NaOH (0.08 g, 2.00 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) was stirred for 1 h and sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel container. The container was heated to 150 °C and held at this temperature for 72 h. It was then cooled to 100 °C at a rate of 5 °C·h−1 and held at this temperature for 8 h. Further cooling to 30 °C at a rate of 3 °C·h−1 followed. The initial and final pH values for 1 were 7.02 and 6.80, respectively. The colorless crystals of 1 were collected in 50.6% yield (0.164 g). Synthesis of 1,4-Bis(2-ethyl-imidazol-1-yl)butane (L4)

A mixture of 2-ethylimidazole (6.80 g, 100 mmol) and NaOH (4.00 g, 100 mmol) in DMSO (20 mL) was stirred at 60 °C for 1 h, and the 1,4-bis(chloro)butane (6.35 g, 50 mmol) was added. The mixture was cooled to room temperature after being stirred at 60 °C for 24 h. The DMSO was then removed and extracted with ethyl acetate (100 × 3). The extracted solution was put in a water bath (90 °C) for 3 h, and the colorless oil L4 was obtained in 70% yield (8.61 g).

Synthesis of 1,3-Bis[2-(2-pyridyl)imidazol-1-ylmethyl]benzene (L5)

A mixture of 2-(2-pyridyl)imidazole (7.25 g, 50 mmol) and NaOH (2.00 g, 50 mmol) in DMSO (20 mL) was stirred at 60 °C for 1 h, and the 1,3-bis(chloromethyl)benzene (4.35 g, 25 mmol) was added. The mixture was cooled to room temperature after being stirred at 60 °C for 24 h and poured into 200 mL of water. A yellow solid formed immediately, which was isolated by filtration in 80% yield (7.84 g) after drying in air.

Synthesis of 1,2-Bis[2-(2-pyridyl)imidazol-1-ylmethyl]benzene (L6)

L6 was prepared in the same way as L5, by using 1,2-bis(chloromethyl)benzene instead of 1,3-bis(chloromethyl)benzene (75% yield (7.35 g)).

cln_elements.content: For compound 1, the weight loss corresponding to the release of water molecules is observed from 30 to 290 °C (obsd 4.2%, calcd 4.3%). The anhydrous composition begins to decompose at 310 °C. The TGA curve of 2 shows that this compound undergoes dehydration between 20 and 136 °C (obsd 5.6%, calcd 2.4%). The decomposition of the anhydrous composition occurs at 286 °C. For compound 3, the weight loss between 60 and 156 °C corresponds to the release of lattice−water molecules (obsd 5.6%, calcd 5.9%). The removal of the organic components occurs at 292 °C. In the case of 4, there is a weight loss of 3.2% (calcd 2.3%) below 189 °C (probably resulting from the very slow absorbability of guest molecules from the air at room temperature), and the decomposition of the anhydrous composition occurs at 297 °C. For 5, the weight loss of 9.2% (calcd 9.3%) between 20 and 285 °C is attributed to the release of the lattice−water and coordination molecules, and the release of the residual [Zn2(BPTC)(L5)] occurs at 290 °C. Compound 6 loses its water molecules between room temperature and 270 °C (obsd 3.6%, calcd 3.6%). The anhydrous [Cd2(BPTC)(L5)] is stable up to 345 °C. Compound 7 loses its water molecules between room temperature and 174 °C (obsd 2.4%, calcd 2.6%). The anhydrous composition is stable up to 269 °C.
